metadata.titleEn: Future projection data set of surface meteorological elements in East Asia (2006-2098)
metadata.description: The RCM employed is the International Center for Theoretical Physics (ICTP) Regional Climate Model version 4 (RegCM4, Giorgi et al., 2012). The domain used is the Coordinated Regional Climate Downscaling Experiment (CORDEX) Phase II East Asia domain, covering whole of China and its surrounding East Asia areas. The model is run at 25 km gird spacing, with its standard configuration of 18 vertical sigma layers with a model top at 10 hPa. Configuration of the model follows Gao et al. (2016, 2017), with land cover data over China was updated as reported by Han et al. (2015) to better represent the realistic vegetation. The initial and lateral boundary conditions needed to drive RegCM4 are derived from the CMIP5 models of HadGEM2-ES (RCP4.5 pathways), and the data set include temperature and precipitation.
metadata.instructions: File name: the temperature and precipitation data are stored in NC format, and the file name is ea_sts.2006-2098.mon.xy.nc, which represents the future projection of temperature and precipitation in the simulation area from January 2006 to December 2098.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the regional climate model used for meteorological element projections in East Asia for the period 2006-2098?
Feature Specification.Answer: RegCM4, horizontal resolution of 25 km, 18 vertical layers, top layer at 10 hPa, updated land cover data for China, initial and boundary conditions from CMIP5 HadGEM2-ES, RCP4.5 scenario, temperature and precipitation elements.

Quantification.Question: What is the horizontal resolution of the regional climate model used for predicting future meteorological elements in East Asia?

Comparison.Question: How do data collection techniques using the RegCM4 regional climate model compare to those using other regional climate models in terms of accuracy and resolution for predicting future meteorological elements in East Asia?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection technique using the RegCM4 regional climate model involves a horizontal resolution of 25 km and vertical layers extending up to 10 hPa, specifically for the East Asia region recommended by CORDEX Phase II. It incorporates updated land cover data for China to describe vegetation conditions, as per Gao et al. (2016, 2017) and Han Zhenyu et al. (2015). The initial and boundary conditions are provided by the CMIP5 global climate model HadGEM2-ES under the RCP4.5 scenario, focusing on temperature and precipitation elements. Comparatively, other regional climate models may differ in spatial resolution, vertical stratification, and input data sources, affecting the precision and applicability of future meteorological predictions in East Asia.

Interpretation.Question: How might the horizontal resolution of 25 km and vertical layering up to 10 hPa in a dataset influence the accuracy and detail of climate predictions for East Asia?
Interpretation.Answer: The horizontal resolution of 25 km allows for relatively detailed spatial representation of climate phenomena, capturing regional variability within East Asia. The vertical layering up to 10 hPa provides a comprehensive view of atmospheric processes, contributing to more accurate climate predictions by capturing interactions between different atmospheric layers. This can enhance the ability to model complex climate dynamics and predict future trends in temperature and precipitation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in setting up a regional climate model to simulate future climate conditions over East Asia, specifically considering the use of RegCM4 with updates to land cover data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The regional climate model (RCM) setup involves using the RegCM4 model with a horizontal resolution of 25 km and vertical stratification into 18 layers up to 10 hPa. The simulation area is defined as the recommended region for the CORDEX Phase II East Asia, covering China and surrounding regions. The model's parameter settings are based on previous work by Gao et al. (2016, 2017) and include updated land cover data for China to accurately describe vegetation conditions. Initial and lateral boundary conditions are derived from the CMIP5 global climate model HadGEM2-ES simulations under the RCP4.5 scenario. The primary meteorological parameters included in the data are temperature and precipitation.
